title: "Imitation of Life" is a thought-provoking drama about race and identity
summary: Sarah and Nora struggle to find their place in the world with regards to their identity. Both women feel that they are betraying their identities when they are forced to pass as something they are not. This film explores the idea that appearances are what matter most in society, and that a personâ€™s social class is the most important thing about them. In the film, George is the son of a rich man, who prefers to keep him in the poorer section of the business so he can remain in control.

content.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...a}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...a,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"The Importance of Identity"),mdx("p",null,"Throughout the film, Sarah and Nora struggle to find their place in the world with regards to their identity. Sarah\u2019s light skin means she can pass as white but her brother cannot. Meanwhile, Nora\u2019s dark skin means she can pass as black but her daughter cannot. As a child, Sarah is repeatedly told that because she is light-skinned, she is special and not like the other \u2018darkies\u2019. Yet when she grows up, her skin colour is a barrier to her happiness and she has to pass as white to find a suitable husband. Meanwhile, Nora is also told that she is special because she is dark-skinned, yet she is poor and cannot marry the man she loves. Both women feel that they are somehow betraying their identities when they are forced to pass as something they are not. "),mdx("h2",null,"Passing and Authenticity"),mdx("p",null,"When Nora\u2019s son asks her if she is \u201Cas black as ","[she]"," can be\u201D, she replies, \u201CI\u2019m as black as I can afford to be!\u201D This line expresses both the idea that to be as authentic as possible is to be genuine, yet it also references the fact that we all make choices about what level of \u2018authenticity\u2019 we present ourselves with. When Nora and George pass for white, they are not being authentic to themselves; they are choosing to present themselves as something they are not. When George tells his wife he would \u201Crather be dead\u201D than go back to Africa, he is being less authentic than Nora who has no problem returning home. Yet the two are punished for their choices with tragic consequences. "),mdx("h2",null,"Cultural Framing of Race"),mdx("p",null,"This film critiques the idea that some races are naturally better than others. It is a common idea that leads to much of the discrimination and racism that exists in society. It is explored through the relationship between Sarah\u2019s boyfriend Harry and her mother Nora. Harry is passionate about jazz and wants to be a professional singer, while Nora works as a waitress and is unimpressed by his \u201Cnoisy music\u201D. Nora refuses to see Harry as an equal, despite the fact that he is a hard-working, intelligent man who shares many of her interests. She refuses to acknowledge that he has the right to pursue his passions, and feels that he is less of a person because of his \u2018lower-class\u2019 status. While she does change her mind about Harry and recognises his worth later in the story, this scene offers insight into the ways cultural prejudice can affect our relationships. "),mdx("h2",null,"Classism"),mdx("p",null,"Classism is the privileging of one segment of society over another based on their financial status. In the film, George is the son of a rich man, who prefers to keep him in the poorer section of the business so he can remain in control. When George and Nora fall in love, she cannot be with him because of his social class. Later, when George has changed his appearance and is posing as a white man, he is able to be with Vida, a rich woman who is his new employer\u2019s daughter. This film explores the idea that appearances are what matter most in society, and that a person\u2019s social class is the most important thing about them. "),mdx("h2",null,"Pansexuality?"),mdx("p",null,"During the film, George often comments that he \u201Cthinks like a woman\u201D. He is shown to have a remarkably empathetic nature that likely has something to do with his decision to marry Vida and pass as white. He recognizes that her desire to marry a white man stems from a desire to be admired and validated by everyone around her. Yet he is also shown to be a devoted father and husband and genuinely in love with Vida. George is also impulsive and temperamental, making impulsive decisions that do not always work out for the best. Despite this, he is given the label of \u2018woman\u2019, suggesting that he is not a man to be taken seriously because of his emotional tendencies. "),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"Released in the year of cinema\u2019s first black Best Actor winner, this film is a thought-provoking melodrama about passing as a marker of authenticity. Rather than any superficial discussion of how many different kinds of people there are or whether one kind is better than another, it is an examination of what it means to be an individual in society by exploring the challenges that arise when one appears to be something they are not. "),mdx("p",null,"This film offers commentary on racial identity, classism and even pansexuality through these characters, providing insight into their experiences and highlighting inequality wherever it exists."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Hip hop music is a universal language. It has proven to be a way for people from different cultures and backgrounds to come together and express themselves. From its humble beginnings in New York City, hip hop has grown into a worldwide sensation, with local scenes spawning in cities across the globe. This article explores the history of hip-hop music, from its roots as an underground movement in the early 1980s to its predominance as one of the most popular genres today.
Fans of rap music are undoubtedly aware that this style of music has origins in New York City during the 1970s and 1980s, but there is much more to know about how exactly it came about and how it evolved over time. From breakdancing to rapping, we\u2019ll explore all of the elements that blended together to form what we now call \u201Chip-hop\u201D today.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Bts's 'Love Yourself: Tear' Is a Triumph

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In a world where every band is a boy band, BTS stands out. The Korean sextet has made a name for itself as not just another boy band but one that plays its own instruments and has choreographed dance routines that are so intricate they sometimes require special stage lighting.
Armed with these weapons, BTS has twice cracked the top 10 on the Billboard 200 album chart with its Love Yourself series. And the latest installment of this series \u2014 which doubles as its sixth EP \u2014 is no exception.
Furthermore, it\u2019s the strongest of the bunch.
It\u2019s impossible to talk about BTS without mentioning their massive following beyond Korea: Vivid, obsessive ARMYs (as they call them) who follow their every move and buy everything associated with them. This is why many people assume they are only famous because of social media and pandering ads (which is true). However, anyone who listens to their music will tell you that they deserve all this success. \u201CLove Yourself: Tear\u201D proves it once again.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Rappers That Will Make You Want to Get Out on the Floor and Dance

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"As hip-hop continues to shed its once-maligned reputation and become increasingly popular, we\u2019ve seen a related boom in mainstream rap music. More than ever before, people are listening to and talking about rappers. But with so much of the genre becoming commodified and predictable, it can be difficult for new artists to stand out among the noise. Fortunately, just because most popular rap fails to break any molds doesn\u2019t mean that the genre is completely devoid of creative talent. In fact, there are a number of rappers who have been working hard to maintain their integrity while still appealing to a larger audience. If you\u2019re ready to put on your dancing shoes and get out on the floor with one of these 10 amazing rappers who will make you want to dance:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Haim's 'Something to Tell You' Is a Delightful Pop Album

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`It\u2019s been almost three years since we heard new music from HAIM, the sister trio from Calabasas that burst onto the music scene in 2014 with their debut album \u2018Days Are Gone.\u2019
With their sophomore album, \u2018Something to Tell You,\u2019 HAIM continues to be optimistic and uplifting with their new music. The album is a mix of upbeat pop tracks and slower ballads that showcase the sisters\u2019 harmony and vocals. Even if you aren't a fan of pop music, it's worth giving this album a listen.
The trio had been working on this album for some time before releasing it. In September 2016, they released three singles; \u201CRight Now,\u201D \u201CNew York Excuse\u201D and \u201CSentimentality.\u201D
And after a year-long hiatus following the release of these songs, HAIM announced via Instagram in June 2017 that they would finally be releasing their second studio album (and first extended play) later that year.
Luckily for us, they stuck to their word and released the nine-track EP on Sept. 14, just in time for our listening pleasure. Here are some of our favorite tracks from HAIM's 'Something To Tell You' Album:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Imitation Game" Is a Fascinating Look at the Life of Alan Turing

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In 1937, Alan Turing was born in Northern England. He would go on to become a war hero, pioneer of computer science, and one of the greatest minds of the 20th century. In 1951, he was convicted of \u201Cgross indecency\u201D and chemically castrated as punishment. Two years later, he killed himself with cyanide. This is his story.
Turing was a brilliant man with many interests that went beyond mathematics and computer science: chess, cryptography, music theory and programming computers to sing are just some examples. This diverse background helped him crack the Nazi Enigma code during World War II at Bletchley Park (which has been nicknamed "Codebreaking Castle"). This saved countless lives and accelerated the end of the war by two years. After the war ended in 1945, Turing continued working as an cryptanalyst for a few more years before turning his attention to other interests \u2013- and it is these interests that led to his arrest and untimely death at age 41.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
